content.description:
Make your way to the large ledge and continue up the chimney. The edges of the chimney are very featured so most people don't bother actually going inside the chimney. Continue up the beautiful finger crack above then traverse left a bit on blocky features before moving up to a bolted anchor.

Look up for the chimney off the ledge that narrows into a crack.
standard rack

climbs.name: 5.9 for Style
climbs.fa: C. Hall, L. Toron, K. McClellan 2009

content.description:
Climb the crack system to the right of the chimney of 5.8 for Style which arcs left and crosses over that route. Climb the finger crack to the left of 5.8 for Style then join that route for the top.

standard rack

One of the best 5.9's at Cochrane Lane.

Climb up an awkward mini ramp or easy climbing left of the mini ramp to a crack and ledge. Traverse right about 7' into a finger crack, past some horizontals and into another vertical crack. Up this and when it gets hard, reach right to gain a blocky ledge. Step back left into the crack above and follow it to the top. 


near where the approach trail meets the cliff. Starts in front of a boulder at the base of the cliff.

standard rack. rap ring anchor

climbs.name: Air Duster Equinox
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Dom Caron, September 2021

content.description:
A very interesting and thought provoking route. Steep crack/face climbing leads to the first crux protected by a bolt. After mantling onto a sloping ledge move up towards an arete under a huge roof. Climb the arete clipping another bolt just under the left edge of the roof. Make a move out left onto the face then straight up to a narrow ledge. Follow a short slab right to the top of the wall. 

Roof Variation: instead of moving left onto the face go right under the roof to a slab then make your way to the top (5.6 G).



This route is found on the right hand side of Minky Wall. Start right of Smoking Crack in a steep, diagonal hand/finger crack. 

Standard Welsford rack. Double .3 to .75. Two protection bolts. Bolted anchor. Rap the route.

Climb the face aiming for the right end of the alcove. Just before the alcove, make some technical moves on crimps with gear below your feet. After the alcove, pull the crux using a flaring crack and a few face holds. Easy climbing to rap rings shared with Bolts are for Kids.



Start below the alcove, aim for it's right end.


Standard rack to #4 BD

climbs.name: Bird of Prey
climbs.fa: G. Hughes and M. Martin, July, 2021

content.description:
Nice variation of Bird of Fire with a bolt protected crux. Start on Bird of Fire. At almost the halfway point break right toward a piton. Make thoughtful moves to gain a diagonal crack leading right then straight up to a bolt protected crux. Make intricate moves to gain a horizontal crack above the bolt then continue straight up to the top of the wall. 


Found on the far left hand side of Minkey just right of a big stump. 

Standard rack to 2" piece. You could double up on small cams. There is one fixed pin in good condition and one bolt. Tree anchor. Rap the route or from the Bird of Fire rap station.

Climb moderate to easy terrain to an alcove, moving just right of the protruding blocks. Move a little left at the alcove and continue up the face. Plug some gear and pull a technical right-trending crux. Easy climbing to rap rings shared with Bird of Fire.



Start right of the broken corner at the far left of Minkey.


standard rack to #3 BD

Shares the start with Sinusoidal. Start just left of the low roof. Climb up easy terrain to a stance then angle left, following a left trending crack past a few tough slopey moves. Continue up to a stance below the hand crack in the roof. Shake out then fire the roof. A few more easy moves lead to the anchor.


In the middle of the Minkey roof there is a left-angling hand crack. That's what you're aiming for.
Standard rack to BD #4. Doubles in finger-sized pieces

This climb is more of a variation/linkup with only the middle section being independent but is quite fun and worth doing. Start is shared with Reno Dyhedro and the end is shared with Inhuman Erazer Direct.

Climb the corner pull the roof and trend up and left as for Reno. After clipping the second bolt of Reno, move up and right to another bolt and positive holds. Make difficult moves up and right to meet Inhuman Erazer just below its upper crux.


Slightly left of where the approach meets the cliff, start below a roof that's about 25' up.
4 bolts, single rack.

Start by gaining the ledge 5m off the ground as for the neighbouring routes. Pull straight over a small roof and into a small alcove above the roof. Continue up flakes then up the face, angling slightly right and gaining a horizontal and a good stance. Move up and left into a crack system that arches left and joins the last few metres of Human Erazer Direct. 



Starts just left of a boulder at the base of the cliff. Shared start with Human Erazer Direct

Standard rack. Doubles in small-medium. Rap rings

Climb up easily to a ledge and follow the left leaning crack Next crack system right of 5.9 for Style.
Basically locate the triangle shaped chimney of 5.8 for Style, the arcing crack to the right is 5.9 for Style, and the next crack system is Curried Recollection. standard rack

Make a few moves up the corner before following features slightly right and up to a protruding finger of rock. Follow a vertical crack to a horizontal, move left and then up right-slanting features. Continue past more horizontals to the top.



Far left of Minkey. Start is either in the obvious corner or in a left-angling crack system just right of the corner.

standard rack, doubles in finger sizes. tree anchor

Climb up to a ledge/stance. Reach right around the corner and clip the bolt. Climb the buttress to a good stance. Step left and pull a couple moves to get to the easier climbing trending left (this part is very close to Warm and Sultry). Pull a bouldery sequence on the face before reaching more discontinuous cracks just left of the Smoking Crack. A final crack arcs left and offers fun moves to the topout just below a tree. 

This route might share a hold or two with its neighbours but mostly climbs the features in between. Slightly contrived here and there but a nice route worth doing.


Look for a bolt on a face down and left of the huge detached flake.
1 bolt, standard rack. Doubles in finger sized might be handy.

Start in the same spot as for A Warm and Sultry Evening. After gaining the second of 2 consecutive small ledges, step slightly left, pull over a small roof and mantle into a small alcove. Climb up some flakes. From a particularly juggy flake, make your way up and left into a left-trending crack system. About 3/4 of the way up the wall you will get to a comfortable stance. Plug some gear because the next section is a bit runout. Pull straight up onto the face using flaring cracks and crimps, then up easier terrain leading to the top.


Start by a boulder at the base of the cliff.
Standard rack. Save some BD 0.3-0.5 for the horizontal protecting the crux.

Make your way up to a small ledge at the base of the left slanting crack. Follow the crack up hard sections separated by good rests. At 2/3 height when the crack splits, follow the right fork past one final crux before gaining easier climbing to the top.


Just slightly right of where the approach trail meets the cliff. Look for a long left slanting crack which goes up pretty much the whole wall.

medium sized nuts, cams from BD .3 to 2 or 3, doubles in finger sizes. Rap rings.

A great variation to Inhuman Erazer Direct which adds a more sustained finish. 

Start up Inhuman Erazer Direct. At about 2/3 of the way up the wall when the crack forks below the final crux of that route (IED takes the right fork), take the left fork and climb the sustained finger crack past a few horizontals to the top.



Pretty much directly where the approach trail meets the cliff.

Medium sized nuts, cams from BD .2 to 3 with doubles in finger sizes. Rap rings.

This is an obscure line left of Pink Panther that has recently been cleaned and is now getting traffic. A fantastic route with great movement and good gear throughout. The gear is not straightforward but it is all there. Start in a crack system below and left of Pink Panther. Move up the face through discontinuous cracks to an angle piton. Continue up to the roof and a fixed nut. It is best not to clip this otherwise you could create horrible rope drag. There is good gear just left of the fixed nut in a horizontal crack. Pull the roof and move left to a face (crux).  Continue up easier climbing to the top of the wall and anchor off a large Spruce tree.  



Locate a crack system under the left side of the giant roof 20 meters off the deck. Left of Pink Panther. 


Standard rack to 2" piece, double or triple small cams (.1 to .5 BD). Tree anchor. Rap the route.

Steep, juggy climbing with good gear. This route essentially combines the best of two neighbouring routes (Nice and Easy with Beastly Crack).



This route is located between Minkey Wall and King Arthur's Playground. Pick the obvious weakness that goes straight up for 15 feet then branches slightly right to the top. 

Standard rack to a 2 inch piece. Bolted anchor. Rap the route.

climbs.name: The Pink Panther
climbs.fa: Colin Bell, Gilles Lacroix and Fred Doucette.1978  FFA: S. Adamson, J. Marceau, I. MacDonald 1984

content.description:
Look for the step in the roof where it drops in height. That is the feature you are aiming for. The climb starts a bit to the right of there and the first part trends up and left past some cracks to gain a nice ledge. From the ledge, head straight up a beautiful crack to the roof/block. Step right and layback the corner to the higher roof then traverse back left onto the face. Climb up to a horizontal crack and traverse right about 3m. From here easy climbing leads to the top.

This route features beautiful climbing but rope drag can be a serious issue. I do not recommend this route to new 5.10 trad leaders. Be sure to extend your gear with alpine draws and possibly even a 120cm sling or two depending on where you place gear.


Look for the step where the roof drops in height.
Standard Rack. alpine draws/slings to extend gear

Very short little route, just left of the easy gully. Climb a short face past a bolt and some horizontals. End at a tree in the gully. Packs a punch for such a short route.

Just left of the easy gully. Look for a bolt
1 bolt, a few small/medium cams for the horizontals

At a wall already loaded with classic climbs, Reno stands out as one of the best.

Scramble up into a corner of pink/orange rock and follow it to the roof about 8m off the ground. Pull the roof then trend up and left passing bolts and gear placements. (At one point you may see a bolt straight up/right. This is for Crack in a Box). Continue going diagonally up and left into a small left facing corner (bolted). Make a dramatic exit move at the top of the corner and just when you thought it was all over, fight the pump on vertical and horizontal cracks that are not quite as good as you were hoping.

A 60m rope may be just enough to rap in a straight line, but not enough to lower and clean gear since the route trends left quite a bit.


Slightly left of where the approach trail meets the cliff. Look for a left facing corner that leads to a roof 25 ft up.
single rack. 6 bolts

climbs.name: Rules of Engagement
climbs.fa: G. Hughes, S. Bethune, M. Delaney 2018

content.description:
Climb the obvious corner at the far left end of Minkey. Top out on a ledge then continue up aiming for a left angling offwidth/tight chimney. Several horizontal cracks and slopers lead to the top.

At the very left end of Minkey Wall. Start in the obvious corner.
Standard rack to #3 cam. the wide section protects with medium gear at the back.

Climb up to a large ledge. Continue up the left leaning crack.

This route and the routes to its right are in the area commonly known as King Arthur's Playground. From Minkey, follow the cliff right past the gully. Hike down a short hill. This is the first crack system on the left side of King Arthur's.
standard rack

Climb cracks left of the hanging block. Continue past a few ledges/stances until you reach a flaring horizontal seam/crack. Traverse about 2m right to gain a small left facing corner and crack. Follow this crack up and left (crux) until you can gain a good stance below the roof/bulge. Clip a bolt out right, climb over the small roof then a few more easy moves to the anchor. Watch out for the large detached (but solid?) block in the roof. This route shares the start with The Bright Side of Life.
Starts near the middle of Minkey wall, just left of a large hanging block about 15-25 ft up. This route climbs up to the far right end of the prominent roof high up on the wall. cams to #3. Optional #4. Doubles in .3-.5. a set of nuts. bolted anchor

Climb up to a small ledge and corner with wide hands/fist crack. From here either climb the corner crack or reach out onto the face, clip the Good Night Gracie bolt and climb the face. Either way you will gain another ledge. Continue up and right to the huge flake then follow the obvious left leaning crack.

To the left of the gully that separates Minkey and King Arthur's Playground, Look for a huge flake. This route climbs up to the flake and the left leaning crack directly above it.
standard rack. 1 optional bolt if climbing the face.

Climb the right facing corner formed by the large block up onto a ledge. Clip a permadraw then climb up and out the right side of the roof. Above the roof, step back left and follow the left-trending crack system After clipping another bolt, step left to join the top of Sinusoidal. Navigate past the detached block on the far right of the high roof and up to the bolted anchor.


a bit left of where the approach meets the trail, there is a low-ish roof and inset. At the left end of the inset there is a large block which forms a right facing corner. Climb up into this right facing corner.
One permadraw and 2 other bolts. standard rack. bolted anchor

climbs.name: Wabanaki
climbs.fa: G. Hughes, M. Martin and D. Caron, July1, 2021

content.description:
Wabanaki translates to "People of the Dawn', the four Algonquian first nations of eastern Canada. Start below a crack system leading to a face. Make tricky moves to get to a narrow foot ledge. Traverse left to a corner crack. Follow this to a roof. Move left around the roof and then up and slightly right to a large Spruce tree at the top of the wall. 



Found on the left side of Minkey between Pink Panther and Bird of Fire. The start is easy to find. 


Standard to 2" piece. Bring lots of small cams, especially green alien or .3 BD. This climb eats nuts, especially offsets. There is plenty of gear on this route but it is not obvious and you have to work for it. You can easily get back to the ground with a 60 meter rope but tie knots!

Climb up on blocky features to gain the face with a bolt. Continue up discontinuous cracks to a comfortable stance below the roof. Pull straight over the roof and continue easily to the anchor.

Beneath the prominent roof. Look for a bolt half way up the wall.
standard rack. 1 bolt

This is the most visible wall from the farmer's field, sitting high on the hillside about in the middle of Cochrane Lane Cliffs. Minkey is arguably CL's best trad wall with an extremely high concentration of classic routes. The only other wall that could rival Minkey in quality is Joe's Garage. The routes here are all in the 30m range and mostly vertical though a few routes pull through the prominent roof on the center-left part of the wall. Minkey can seem a bit intimidating at first due to its size and imposing appearance but most routes offer good protection. Keep an eye out for the PG rated routes though as they will offer a bit more of a mental challenge.

The right side of Minkey proper (near where the approach trail meets the cliff) can be a bit confusing since several routes climb crack systems that lean to the left and many variations and linkups have been done on this part of the wall. If you are unfamiliar with this part of the wall it's a good idea to take a close look at a topo to make sure you know where your chosen route climbs. That being said, once you know where you are going, all the routes follow logical features and have a nice flow to them.
